Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Word Learning in a Signed Language and Its Relationship to Spoken Word Learning in Hearing Non-Signing Adults

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Between 1990 and 2013, enrollment in American Sign Language (ASL) as a second language in US colleges and universities increased by 6,840%; consequently, in 2013, ASL displaced German as the third most frequently taught second language in US schools of higher education. Despite the dramatic increase in popularity, we know very little about the cognitive processes involved in learning a signed language as a second language or how they relate to the processes involved in learning a spoken language. For example, prior research tells us that brain activation patterns during language processing tasks are quite similar for signers and speakers, but differences are observed in sensory and motor areas--how do these differences affect learning a signed language? Moreover, there is an extensive body of research on cognitive factors that predict spoken language learning success--do some of these factors also predict sign learning success?

In order to begin addressing the questions posed above, this project aims to 1) extend the existing research on cognitive predictors of second language word learning in spoken language to that of signed language and 2) investigate the relationship between second language signed and spoken word learning. In order to accomplish these aims, the researchers will conduct a multivariate modeling study assessing short-term memory, working memory, reasoning, vocabulary knowledge, and word learning in hearing non-signing adults and explore how these variables relate to their ability to learn novel signs in the laboratory setting. The results of this project will have theoretical and practical implications. From a theoretical perspective, this project will provide insight into the cognitive components that are common to all languages and those that are unique to either signed or spoken languages. From a practical perspective, the results of this study will aid in the development of diagnostic and predictive language assessments that teachers, students, and organizations can use when considering second language courses.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The aim of this study was to investigate sign learning ability and its relationship to word learning ability in hearing adult non-signers. While there is an abundance of research investigating cognitive processes related to word learning, far fewer studies have investigated sign learning ability and fewer still have investigated the relationship between sign and word learning. This is unfortunate because a growing number of high school and college students are electing to enroll in sign language courses and research of this type can inform pedagogical practices. Moreover, we can gain further insight into one of humanity’s defining characteristics by investigating the cognitive processes that are common to all languages and those that are unique to signed or spoken languages.

 

To that end, 236 participants completed 25 tasks assessing word learning, sign learning, short-term memory, and intelligence. The results indicated that sign and word learning ability are highly correlated. This strong relationship is partly due to hearing non-signers using auditory-verbal processes to facilitate sign learning. Additionally, both sign and word learning rely on fluid intelligence and short-term memory abilities, however language modality specific processes (e.g., auditory vs. visual-spatial) also account for differences in performance. Future studies should investigate whether these factors account for differences in classroom performance and whether they do so similarly in both signed and spoken language courses.

 

For more information and for access to some of the task materials used in this study, see https://osf.io/xmype/
